Because it has a T c of 39 K, MgB is expected to be used around 20 K (which can be easily achieved by liquid hydrogen and a cryocooler), replacing practical low-temperature superconductors (LTS, such as Nb- Ti, Nb 3 Sn) used in liquid helium.
Since the superconductivity of MgB 2 was reported in 2001 [1], MgB 2 has attracted wide interest for both basic research and practical applications.
